text: hi everyone phineas here the internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review of the new carcass album torn
arteries this is a brand new lp from uk
death metal legends carcass they are now
two albums deep into their comeback
which they reformed in the 2000s but it
wasn't until the 2010s that we saw the
record surgical steel which was a solid
return but one also where the band
decided to play to expectations a bit by
dishing out another helping of the
flashy brisk and infectious melodic
death metal of their 1993 record heart
work so yes 20 years later with surgical
steel they pretty much showed that sound
still had you know gas left in the tank
and now eight years later they're kinda
hitting us with the same sound again
which may be a little surprising for
fans who are familiar with how varied
the band's early work is but i guess for
another lp this is a pretty obvious way
to go about things given that heart work
is
easily the band's most influential work
ever plus carcasses 2020 despicable ep
didn't exactly forecast a change of pace
either the song under the scalpel blade
from that project even made it onto torn
arteries so there you go yes in one
breath it is unfortunate that torn
arteries isn't showing the band breaking
any new ground or you know besting their
classic stuff but it still sounds pretty
good to have carcass playing to their
strengths and having fun while doing it
i mean the cover here with the cheeky
heart made of vegetables looks like a
vegan meme i would see on instagram then
from there we have titles on this lp
like kelly's meat emporium and eleanor
riga mortis guitarist bill steer isn't
exactly holding back on those super
colorful leads and harmonies either as
their spots on this lp where he really
seems to be indulging in sounds and
styles that he may have like a personal
nostalgia for this may very solidly be a
death metal album but there are some
licks and solos here and there that
might have some blues undertones or like
hard rock undertones the lengthy solo
passage on flesh ripping sonic torment
limited gives off big david gilmore
vibes though does fall a little short of
having that classic pink floyd finesse
still the band as a whole though is
sounding as tight as ever with pretty
much every song hitting a deadly pace
with gruesome lead vocals thrashy riffs
and a heavy metal melodicism the
addition of dan wilding on drums is
still paying off his fills are monstrous
and his beats are consistently
aggressive especially on those blasts i
also love the little nuances he throws
in to his cymbal work on the groovier
passages of the record too like on the
whole there's nothing really off about
this lp no huge glaring flaws even the
production is super clean and punchy
without taking away that that feel that
vibe of an organic performance but with
carcass playing it so safe on this lp i
think they are seeing some diminishing
returns which was already the case for
surgical steel but now slightly more so
like for example the title track is
pretty blistering and goes off without a
hitch but also not without much to latch
onto in terms of a great groove great
riff or memorable melody slightly slower
and more varied cuts like dance of ix
top as well as eleanor leave a stronger
impression especially with the latter's
speed metal intro chunky verse riffs and
sinister guitar harmonies under the
scalpel blade does bring some of the
heavier and more mosh friendly riffs on
the entire record but i'm surprised it's
this song and this song alone from the
despicable ep that made it onto the
record especially when the living dead
at the manchester morgue was so much
more anthemic and epically structured
the devil rides out is pure heavy metal
theatrics but done with the
extreme and gruesome riffs and vocals
that carcass are known for it's what's
to be expected at this point but it's
done well meanwhile kelly's meat
emporium manages to be one of the
catchiest tracks the band's ever
recorded like the way the hook comes in
right as those blast beats are hitting
are you kidding me crashing yourself in
god we trust may have one of the
simplest riffs on the project but it
does hit a really nasty 16th note groove
i also love the breakaways on this track
into these slower more melodic passages
as well that are super tasteful shows
the band at this point can pull off
something equally brutal and beautiful
plus are those hand claps in the mix at
a few different points because
that's kind of cool wake up and smell
the carcass and caveat emptor also find
a lot of power and variation with
multiple phases of rifts and solos and
mellow breaks all flowing into each
other flawlessly and the closing the
scythe's remorseless swing sees the band
bringing more theatrics to the table
especially on the vocal end where i
believe they treat uh the singing with
some effects to make them sound like
they're coming through a speaker of some
kind either way it draws some very
necessary attention to those vocals
which seem a little bit more
intelligible here than they are on the
rest of the lp because the band really
wants you to focus on this meditation on
all of us being on death's time the
shelf life of our mortality you know
death metal things with some absolutely
righteous riffs and drums to go along
with it it's a pretty kick-ass ending
for a record that ends a little stronger
than it starts so yeah overall this new
carcass while it's not super ambitious
it is a well-written performed
hard-hitting and somewhat catchy melodic
death metal record uh feeling a light to
decent seven on this one tran position
have you given this album a listen did
you love it did you hate it what would
you rate it you're the best you're the
best what should i review next hit the
like if you like please subscribe and
please don't cry hit the bell as well
over here next to my head it's another
video you can check out hit that up or
the link to subscribe to the channel
anthony fantano
carcass of forever
